awd_titl_txt: Connecting Junction Molecular Orientation to Excited State Structure and Dynamics in Organic Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Printable electronic devices based on flexible organic-based materials have the potential to revolutionize how we renewably harvest and store energy. The arrangement of plastic molecules at interfaces between layers can determine whether the device performs well. However, there is currently limited knowledge of how such arrangements govern device performance. In this project, solar cells and light emitters printed from plastic inks are studied. These devices have important interfaces where power is generated and light is emitted. This project involves varying the arrangement of the molecules at these interfaces, monitored by powerful X-ray techniques. Correspondingly, power- and light-generating processes are measured and related to the arrangement of the molecules. The result will be a new capability to tailor molecule arrangements at interfaces to maximize device performance. Such a capability will enable flexible and printable technologies to dramatically reduce the cost of energy. Students involved in this project will take part in the Science Ambassadors Program by developing a plastic solar cell lab for high school students. This activity will demonstrate both the fundamental science and the potential of these technologies. The interdisciplinary and collaborative nature of the project will provide the students with expertise to communicate diverse viewpoints that will be required of the next generation of scientists.

Optoelectronic properties in printable organic devices could be tailored for revolutionary applications through simple processing techniques that engineer interfacial structures, but there is a gap in knowledge to realize this goal. This gap is due to the difficulty in quantitatively resolving buried organic interfacial nanostructure and directly correlating this to fundamental device processes. In the proposed work, a suite of recently developed resonant X-ray nanoprobes will be used to quantify molecular orientation, aggregation, and mixing local to buried organic interfaces. These measurements will be combined with advanced studies of excited state structure and dynamics on the exact same device - eliminating uncertainties related to sample variability. The objective is to define quantitative relationships on how molecular ordering at buried organic junctions controls excited state dynamics connected to performance. It will be accomplished by systematically investigating all structural cases in planar junctions and extending this information to printed 3D heterojunctions. Our aim is not only to establish the general concepts, but to define the functional form of these relationships to enable designed properties in high-performing organic devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project advanced performance of printable organic electronics for energy and biosensing, improved capabilities to probe key organic interfaces in devices, and contributed toward the next generation of leading STEM researchers.

Intellectual Merit:

Our work on organic solar cells for power generation focused on a key interface in the device where light is converted to electrical power. We found that fabrication strategies that make these interfaces sharper (more abrupt) and more crystalline had two critical effects: First sharp, crystalline interfaces enable increased generation of electricity and second, once generated, the electricity was output by the device more successfully. This indicates that ink-printing strategies for device fabrication should focus on mechanisms that sharpen and crystallize these interfaces while the ?ink dries.?

Our work on organic devices for biosensing focused on improving the speed, control, and sensing of bio-signals in the body and brain known as ions. We found that a nanochannel (interface) could act as an ion superhighway in devices, setting a new record of ion speed. Furthermore, certain molecules in contact with this channel could enhance or repel ions from the highway, showing up as an electrical signal detected by a computer. This new capability could be used in a host of medical, robotics, and computing technologies.

In order to complete this work on investigating interfaces in organic devices, we had to invent or improve ways to measure interfacial organic structure and dynamics. For example, we developed a novel X-ray nanoprobe that is intrinsically sensitive to each molecule type based only on the atomic bonds in the molecule. We also invented a new and improved way to measure the electrical power generated at the key solar cell interface using special voltage pulses in concert with a pulsed laser. Putting both new capabilities together, we were able to track and connect changes at the interface with increased electrical power generation there.

Broader Impact:

The discoveries and advancements we have achieved will have broad impact in technologies involved in sustainable energy harvesting and medical devices. Flexible and light weight solar panels printed from inks on a massive scale will enable solar to become a major contributor to energy production ? significantly displacing fossil fuels. Our new understanding of improving how the interface generates power contributes to this future outcome. On the other hand, our discovery that ions can be accelerated and controlled at an interface and sensed by a computer in organic devices, contributes toward improved medical technologies where biosignals (ions) reveal conditions of the body and brain to a level unobservable with current technologies.

In general, our new understanding of how organic nano-interfaces work in solar cells and biosensors is applicable to a host of other technologies that depend on the same interfaces such as organic LED displays, organic transistors, and neuromorphic computing. Furthermore, our advancement of new ways to measure nanoscale structure and dynamics will be used to probe organic materials in ways not possible before ? connecting nanostructure to materials properties to new technological capabilities.

Finally, this project has supported the education and preparation of the next generation of STEM researchers. It has supported the thesis projects of four undergraduate students at Washington State University and two undergraduate students completing summer internship projects from small colleges that don?t have research programs. The grant has supported one Masters thesis in physics and three PhD projects in Materials Science and Engineering. Finally, this work has supported the scientific and professional development of a postdoctoral scholar who was a first-generation college student and is now a staff scientist at a major national laboratory. The work has further led to twelve peer-reviewed publications documenting these discoveries as well as 17 presentations at major conferences, universities, and civic organizations (e.g. Rotary).

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2022
Modified by: Brian Collins
